name: Persian

intro: Persian cats are gentle, affectionate companions with significant health risks due to their flat faces and genetic predispositions. They're prone to polycystic kidney disease (PKD), breathing difficulties, and chronic eye problems. Insurance is essential for managing these ongoing costs.
whyInsurance: Persians face PKD (requires lifelong monitoring and treatment), breathing issues from their flat faces, and chronic eye conditions needing regular care. These aren't one-time costs—they're ongoing expenses throughout your cat's life.
mustHave: Hereditary condition coverage — PKD is extremely common in Persians

Eye condition coverage — Multiple hereditary eye problems
No per-condition limits — Ongoing costs add up fast

costIntro: Persian cats have moderate to high insurance costs due to their health risks. Here's what to expect:

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for a Persian cat?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Persians are one of the highest-risk breeds due to PKD, breathing issues, and eye problems. Most Persians will need ongoing veterinary care, making insurance a smart investment.

faqs.question: What is PKD in Persian cats?
faqs.answer: Polycystic Kidney Disease causes cysts to form in the kidneys. It's hereditary and affects up to 40% of Persians. There's no cure, but early detection and management can extend quality of life. Insurance helps cover ongoing monitoring and treatment.

faqs.question: Do all insurance companies cover Persian cats?
faqs.answer: Most do, but some have restrictions on brachycephalic (flat-faced) breeds. Always confirm hereditary conditions and breathing issues are covered before purchasing.

faqs.question: Are Persian cats expensive to insure?
faqs.answer: Slightly higher than average due to their health risks, but not the most expensive. Expect to pay $25-50/month for good coverage. The cost is justified given their likelihood of health issues.

faqs.question: Should I get a wellness plan for my Persian?
faqs.answer: Consider it. Persians benefit from regular dental cleanings (due to overcrowded teeth) and eye exams. A wellness plan can help offset these routine costs.
